newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Egana says to expand jewellery business.
newsitem.headline: Egana says to expand jewellery business.

text.p: Watch and jewellery products manufacturer and distributor Egana International (Holdings) Ltd expects jewellery operations to contribute about 50 percent of the company's sales revenue in three to five years' time.
"We will gradually expand our jewellery business, taking advantage of a relatively cheaper labour cost in Asia," said Egana's chairman Hans-Joerg Seeberger in a press briefing on Wednesday.
"And in three to five years' time, we anticipate 50 percent of our sales revenue to be from timepieces and 50 percent from jewellery," Seeberger said.
Jewellery operations currently contribute just over 22 percent of the company's turnover, said director David Wong.
Seeberger said he expected strong growth in consumer spending for luxury products in Asia and the United States in coming years while Europe would remain as a mass market for the goods.

"We will consider a spinoff of our jewellery operation in future if the time is appropriate," Egana's executive director Peter Lee said. "However, we do not have any detail planning on the spinoff at this stage."

In order to expand its jewellery business, Lee said the company had bought a 45 percent stake in Thai jewellery maker and distributor Keimothai Ltd for about HK$10 million from Keimothai's 92.5 percent controlling founder Kurt Keller.
Keimothai manufactures and distributes fine jewellery. Its customers include Christ Holding GmbH and Tiffany.

The company had said the purchase would expand the geographical coverage of its jewellery products to Thailand and strengthen the relationship with Christ, a company which has over 450 jewellery and timepiece retail chain stores in Germany and Switzerland.
In December, Seeberger placed 15 million Egana shares, or about a one percent stake, at HK$1.93 each to Christ. Seeberger continues to hold 53.3 percent of Egana after the deal.
Christ is 65.5 percent controlled by Douglas Holding AG which has more than 1,800 specialist stores all over Europe.
Seeberger said a strengthening relation with Christ and Douglas Holding would pave the way to further expand its distribution network in Europe.
Seeberger said Egana would continue to expand its retail network in the U.S. and explore sourcing business cooperation opportunities in Asia.
